facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_035813/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and years
df['AuthorKeywords'] = df['AuthorKeywords'].str.split(', ')
keywords_by_year = df.explode('AuthorKeywords').groupby('Year')['AuthorKeywords'].apply(list)

# Count keyword occurrences by year
keyword_trends = {year: Counter(keywords) for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items()}

# Plot the top keywords over the years
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 8))
for year, counter in keyword_trends.items():
    top_keywords = counter.most_common(3)  # Get top 3 keywords for each year
    for keyword, count in top_keywords:
        plt.bar(year, count, label=keyword)

plt.title('Top 3 Keywords in Sensemaking Research Over Time')
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Keyword Frequency')
plt.legend(title='Keywords')
plt.xticks(sorted(df['Year'].unique()))
plt.show()

# Print the keyword trends
print("### Begin of facts")
for year, counter in keyword_trends.items():
    print(f"Year {year}: {counter.most_common(3)}")
print("### End of facts")

question.question: How has the focus of sensemaking research evolved over time based on the analysis of 'AuthorKeywords' and 'Year'?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_035813/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and years
df['AuthorKeywords'] = df['AuthorKeywords'].str.split(', ')
keywords_by_year = df.explode('AuthorKeywords').groupby('Year')['AuthorKeywords'].apply(list)

# Count keyword occurrences by year
keyword_trends = {year: Counter(keywords) for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items()}

# Plot the top keywords over the years
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 8))
for year, counter in keyword_trends.items():
    top_keywords = counter.most_common(3)  # Get top 3 keywords for each year
    for keyword, count in top_keywords:
        plt.bar(year, count, label=keyword)

plt.title('Top 3 Keywords in Sensemaking Research Over Time')
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Keyword Frequency')
plt.legend(title='Keywords')
plt.xticks(sorted(df['Year'].unique()))
plt.show()

# Print the keyword trends
print("### Begin of facts")
for year, counter in keyword_trends.items():
    print(f"Year {year}: {counter.most_common(3)}")
print("### End of facts")

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

question.question: How has the focus of sensemaking research evolved over time based on the analysis of 'AuthorKeywords' and 'Year'?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_035813/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and years
df['AuthorKeywords'] = df['AuthorKeywords'].str.split(', ')
keywords_by_year = df.explode('AuthorKeywords').groupby('Year')['AuthorKeywords'].apply(list)

# Count keyword occurrences by year
keyword_trends = {year: Counter(keywords) for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items()}

# Plot the top keywords over the years
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 8))
for year, counter in keyword_trends.items():
    top_keywords = counter.most_common(3)  # Get top 3 keywords for each year
    for keyword, count in top_keywords:
        plt.bar(year, count, label=keyword)

plt.title('Top 3 Keywords in Sensemaking Research Over Time')
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Keyword Frequency')
plt.legend(title='Keywords')
plt.xticks(sorted(df['Year'].unique()))
plt.show()

# Print the keyword trends
print("### Begin of facts")
for year, counter in keyword_trends.items():
    print(f"Year {year}: {counter.most_common(3)}")
print("### End of facts")

By 2012, the focus shifted towards semantic interaction and user interaction in visual analytics, indicating a move towards understanding how users interact with data and models to facilitate sensemaking.

The evolution from 2010 to 2012 suggests a broadening of the sensemaking research scope from specific applications like journalism to more generalizable methods and tools in visual analytics, focusing on user interaction and analytical reasoning.

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_035813/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and years
df['AuthorKeywords'] = df['AuthorKeywords'].str.split(', ')

# Flatten the list of keywords with their corresponding years
keywords_years = [(year, keyword) for year, keywords in zip(df['Year'], df['AuthorKeywords']) for keyword in keywords]

# Create a DataFrame from the list
keywords_df = pd.DataFrame(keywords_years, columns=['Year', 'Keyword'])

# Count the occurrences of each keyword per year
keyword_trends = keywords_df.groupby(['Year', 'Keyword']).size().unstack(fill_value=0)

# Plot the top 5 keywords over the years
top_keywords = keyword_trends.sum().nlargest(5).index
keyword_trends[top_keywords].plot(marker='o')
plt.title('Top 5 Keywords in Sensemaking Research Over Time')
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Frequency')
plt.legend(title='Keywords')
plt.grid(True)
plt.show()

# Print the top keywords for each year
print("### Begin of facts")
for year, group in keywords_df.groupby('Year'):
    top_keywords_year = group['Keyword'].value_counts().head(3)
    print(f"Year {year}: {', '.join(top_keywords_year.index)}")
print("### End of facts")

question.question: How has the focus of sensemaking research evolved over time based on the analysis of 'AuthorKeywords' and 'Year'?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_035813/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and years
df['AuthorKeywords'] = df['AuthorKeywords'].str.split(', ')
keywords_by_year = df.explode('AuthorKeywords').groupby('Year')['AuthorKeywords'].apply(list)

# Count keyword occurrences by year
keyword_trends = {year: Counter(keywords) for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items()}

# Plot the top keywords over the years
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 8))
for year, counter in keyword_trends.items():
    top_keywords = counter.most_common(3)  # Get top 3 keywords for each year
    for keyword, count in top_keywords:
        plt.bar(year, count, label=keyword)

plt.title('Top 3 Keywords in Sensemaking Research Over Time')
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Keyword Frequency')
plt.legend(title='Keywords')
plt.xticks(sorted(df['Year'].unique()))
plt.show()

# Print the keyword trends
print("### Begin of facts")
for year, counter in keyword_trends.items():
    print(f"Year {year}: {counter.most_common(3)}")
print("### End of facts")

insights: The dataset shows a progression in the focus of sensemaking research from 2010 to 2012. In 2010, the emphasis was on using social media for journalistic inquiry, highlighting the role of computational journalism and social media in sensemaking. By 2012, the focus shifted towards semantic interaction and user interaction in visual analytics, indicating a move towards understanding how users interact with data and models to facilitate sensemaking.

The 'AuthorKeywords' from 2010 include terms like 'Computational Journalism' and 'Social Media', suggesting an early interest in how digital platforms can aid in sensemaking. In contrast, the 2012 keywords such as 'User Interaction' and 'Analytic Reasoning' reflect a deeper exploration into the cognitive processes and interactions involved in sensemaking.

The evolution from 2010 to 2012 suggests a broadening of the sensemaking research scope from specific applications like journalism to more generalizable methods and tools in visual analytics, focusing on user interaction and analytical reasoning.

import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_035813/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and years
df['AuthorKeywords'] = df['AuthorKeywords'].str.split(', ')

# Flatten the list of keywords with their corresponding years
keywords_years = [(year, keyword) for year, keywords in zip(df['Year'], df['AuthorKeywords']) for keyword in keywords]

# Create a DataFrame from the list
keywords_df = pd.DataFrame(keywords_years, columns=['Year', 'Keyword'])

# Count the occurrences of each keyword per year
keyword_trends = keywords_df.groupby(['Year', 'Keyword']).size().unstack(fill_value=0)

# Plot the top 5 keywords over the years
top_keywords = keyword_trends.sum().nlargest(5).index
keyword_trends[top_keywords].plot(marker='o')
plt.title('Top 5 Keywords in Sensemaking Research Over Time')
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Frequency')
plt.legend(title='Keywords')
plt.grid(True)
plt.show()

# Print the top keywords for each year
print("### Begin of facts")
for year, group in keywords_df.groupby('Year'):
    top_keywords_year = group['Keyword'].value_counts().head(3)
    print(f"Year {year}: {', '.join(top_keywords_year.index)}")
print("### End of facts")

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_035813/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and years
df['AuthorKeywords'] = df['AuthorKeywords'].str.split(', ')
keywords_by_year = df.explode('AuthorKeywords').groupby('Year')['AuthorKeywords'].apply(list)

# Count keyword occurrences by year
keyword_trends = {year: Counter(keywords) for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items()}

# Plot the top keywords over the years
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 8))
for year, counter in keyword_trends.items():
    top_keywords = counter.most_common(3)  # Get top 3 keywords for each year
    for keyword, count in top_keywords:
        plt.bar(year, count, label=keyword)

plt.title('Top 3 Keywords in Sensemaking Research Over Time')
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Keyword Frequency')
plt.legend(title='Keywords')
plt.xticks(sorted(df['Year'].unique()))
plt.show()

# Print the keyword trends
print("### Begin of facts")
for year, counter in keyword_trends.items():
    print(f"Year {year}: {counter.most_common(3)}")
print("### End of facts")

import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_035813/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and years

keywords_by_year = df.explode('AuthorKeywords').groupby('Year')['AuthorKeywords'].apply(list)

keyword_trends = {year: Counter(keywords) for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items()}

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_035813/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and years
df['AuthorKeywords'] = df['AuthorKeywords'].str.split(', ')

# Flatten the list of keywords with their corresponding years
keywords_years = [(year, keyword) for year, keywords in zip(df['Year'], df['AuthorKeywords']) for keyword in keywords]

# Create a DataFrame from the list
keywords_df = pd.DataFrame(keywords_years, columns=['Year', 'Keyword'])

# Count the occurrences of each keyword per year
keyword_trends = keywords_df.groupby(['Year', 'Keyword']).size().unstack(fill_value=0)

# Plot the top 5 keywords over the years
top_keywords = keyword_trends.sum().nlargest(5).index
keyword_trends[top_keywords].plot(marker='o')
plt.title('Top 5 Keywords in Sensemaking Research Over Time')
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Frequency')
plt.legend(title='Keywords')
plt.grid(True)
plt.show()

# Print the top keywords for each year
print("### Begin of facts")
for year, group in keywords_df.groupby('Year'):
    top_keywords_year = group['Keyword'].value_counts().head(3)
    print(f"Year {year}: {', '.join(top_keywords_year.index)}")
print("### End of facts")

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_035813/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and years
df['AuthorKeywords'] = df['AuthorKeywords'].str.split(', ')
keywords_by_year = df.explode('AuthorKeywords').groupby('Year')['AuthorKeywords'].apply(list)

# Count keyword occurrences by year
keyword_trends = {year: Counter(keywords) for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items()}

# Find top keywords for each year
top_keywords_by_year = {year: keywords.most_common(3) for year, keywords in keyword_trends.items()}

# Plot the evolution of top keywords over time
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
for year, keywords in top_keywords_by_year.items():
    for keyword, count in keywords:
        plt.bar(year, count, label=keyword)

plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Keyword Frequency')
plt.title('Evolution of Top Keywords in Sensemaking Research')
plt.legend(loc='upper right')
plt.show()

# Print the top keywords by year
print("### Begin of facts")
for year, keywords in top_keywords_by_year.items():
    print(f"Year {year}: {', '.join([kw for kw, _ in keywords])}")
print("### End of facts")

import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_035813/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and years
df['AuthorKeywords'] = df['AuthorKeywords'].str.split(', ')

# Flatten the list of keywords with their corresponding years
keywords_years = [(year, keyword) for year, keywords in zip(df['Year'], df['AuthorKeywords']) for keyword in keywords]

# Create a DataFrame from the list
keywords_df = pd.DataFrame(keywords_years, columns=['Year', 'Keyword'])

# Count the occurrences of each keyword per year

for year, group in keywords_df.groupby('Year'):
    top_keywords_year = group['Keyword'].value_counts().head(3)
    print(f"Year {year}: {', '.join(top_keywords_year.index)}")
print("### End of facts")

import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_035813/dataset_selected.csv')

# Filter the dataset for the years 2010 to 2012
df_filtered = df[(df['Year'] >= 2010) & (df['Year'] <= 2012)]

# Extract keywords and titles
titles = df_filtered['Title'].str.cat(sep=' ').lower().split()
keywords = df_filtered['AuthorKeywords'].str.cat(sep=',').lower().split(',')

# Count the frequency of words in titles and keywords
title_word_count = Counter(titles)
keyword_count = Counter(keywords)

# Get the most common words in titles and keywords
top_title_words = title_word_count.most_common(5)
top_keywords = keyword_count.most_common(5)

# Print the results
print("### Begin of facts")
print("Top 5 words in titles from 2010 to 2012:")
for word, count in top_title_words:
    print(f"{word}: {count}")

print("\nTop 5 keywords from 2010 to 2012:")
for keyword, count in top_keywords:
    print(f"{keyword}: {count}")
print("### End of facts")

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_035813/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and years
df['AuthorKeywords'] = df['AuthorKeywords'].str.split(', ')
keywords_by_year = df.explode('AuthorKeywords').groupby('Year')['AuthorKeywords'].apply(list)

# Count keyword occurrences by year
keyword_trends = {year: Counter(keywords) for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items()}

# Plot the top keywords over the years
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 8))
for year, counter in keyword_trends.items():
    top_keywords = counter.most_common(3)  # Get top 3 keywords for each year
    for keyword, count in top_keywords:
        plt.bar(year, count, label=keyword)

plt.title('Top 3 Keywords in Sensemaking Research Over Time')
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Keyword Frequency')
plt.legend(title='Keywords')
plt.xticks(sorted(df['Year'].unique()))
plt.show()

# Print the keyword trends
print("### Begin of facts")
for year, counter in keyword_trends.items():
    print(f"Year {year}: {counter.most_common(3)}")
print("### End of facts")

By 2012, the focus shifted towards semantic interaction and user interaction in visual analytics, indicating a move towards understanding how users interact with data and models to facilitate sensemaking.

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_035813/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and years
df['AuthorKeywords'] = df['AuthorKeywords'].str.split(', ')

# Flatten the list of keywords with their corresponding years
keywords_years = [(year, keyword) for year, keywords in zip(df['Year'], df['AuthorKeywords']) for keyword in keywords]

# Create a DataFrame from the list
keywords_df = pd.DataFrame(keywords_years, columns=['Year', 'Keyword'])

# Count the occurrences of each keyword per year
keyword_trends = keywords_df.groupby(['Year', 'Keyword']).size().unstack(fill_value=0)

# Plot the top 5 keywords over the years
top_keywords = keyword_trends.sum().nlargest(5).index
keyword_trends[top_keywords].plot(marker='o')
plt.title('Top 5 Keywords in Sensemaking Research Over Time')
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Frequency')
plt.legend(title='Keywords')
plt.grid(True)
plt.show()

# Print the top keywords for each year
print("### Begin of facts")
for year, group in keywords_df.groupby('Year'):
    top_keywords_year = group['Keyword'].value_counts().head(3)
    print(f"Year {year}: {', '.join(top_keywords_year.index)}")
print("### End of facts")

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_035813/dataset_selected.csv')

# Filter the dataset for the years 2010 to 2012
df_filtered = df[(df['Year'] >= 2010) & (df['Year'] <= 2012)]

# Extract keywords and titles
titles = df_filtered['Title'].str.cat(sep=' ').lower().split()
keywords = df_filtered['AuthorKeywords'].str.cat(sep=',').lower().split(',')

# Count the frequency of words in titles and keywords
title_word_count = Counter(titles)
keyword_count = Counter(keywords)

# Get the most common words in titles and keywords
top_title_words = title_word_count.most_common(5)
top_keywords = keyword_count.most_common(5)

# Print the results
print("### Begin of facts")
print("Top 5 words in titles from 2010 to 2012:")
for word, count in top_title_words:
    print(f"{word}: {count}")

print("\nTop 5 keywords from 2010 to 2012:")
for keyword, count in top_keywords:
    print(f"{keyword}: {count}")
print("### End of facts")

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_035813/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and years
df['AuthorKeywords'] = df['AuthorKeywords'].str.split(', ')
keywords_by_year = df.explode('AuthorKeywords').groupby('Year')['AuthorKeywords'].apply(list)

# Count keyword occurrences by year
keyword_trends = {year: Counter(keywords) for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items()}

# Plot the top keywords over the years
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 8))
for year, counter in keyword_trends.items():
    top_keywords = counter.most_common(3)  # Get top 3 keywords for each year
    for keyword, count in top_keywords:
        plt.bar(year, count, label=keyword)

plt.title('Top 3 Keywords in Sensemaking Research Over Time')
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Keyword Frequency')
plt.legend(title='Keywords')
plt.xticks(sorted(df['Year'].unique()))
plt.show()

# Print the keyword trends
print("### Begin of facts")
for year, counter in keyword_trends.items():
    print(f"Year {year}: {counter.most_common(3)}")
print("### End of facts")

question.question: How has the focus of sensemaking research evolved over time based on the analysis of 'AuthorKeywords' and 'Year'?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_035813/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and years
df['AuthorKeywords'] = df['AuthorKeywords'].str.split(', ')
keywords_by_year = df.explode('AuthorKeywords').groupby('Year')['AuthorKeywords'].apply(list)

# Count keyword occurrences by year
keyword_trends = {year: Counter(keywords) for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items()}

# Plot the top keywords over the years
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 8))
for year, counter in keyword_trends.items():
    top_keywords = counter.most_common(3)  # Get top 3 keywords for each year
    for keyword, count in top_keywords:
        plt.bar(year, count, label=keyword)

plt.title('Top 3 Keywords in Sensemaking Research Over Time')
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Keyword Frequency')
plt.legend(title='Keywords')
plt.xticks(sorted(df['Year'].unique()))
plt.show()

# Print the keyword trends
print("### Begin of facts")
for year, counter in keyword_trends.items():
    print(f"Year {year}: {counter.most_common(3)}")
print("### End of facts")

insights: The dataset shows a progression in the focus of sensemaking research from 2010 to 2012. In 2010, the emphasis was on using social media for journalistic inquiry, highlighting the role of computational journalism and social media in sensemaking. By 2012, the focus shifted towards semantic interaction and user interaction in visual analytics, indicating a move towards understanding how users interact with data and models to facilitate sensemaking.

The 'AuthorKeywords' from 2010 include terms like 'Computational Journalism' and 'Social Media', suggesting an early interest in how digital platforms can aid in sensemaking. In contrast, the 2012 keywords such as 'User Interaction' and 'Analytic Reasoning' reflect a deeper exploration into the cognitive processes and interactions involved in sensemaking.

The evolution from 2010 to 2012 suggests a broadening of the sensemaking research scope from specific applications like journalism to more generalizable methods and tools in visual analytics, focusing on user interaction and analytical reasoning.

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_035813/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and years
df['AuthorKeywords'] = df['AuthorKeywords'].str.split(', ')

# Flatten the list of keywords with their corresponding years
keywords_years = [(year, keyword) for year, keywords in zip(df['Year'], df['AuthorKeywords']) for keyword in keywords]

# Create a DataFrame from the list
keywords_df = pd.DataFrame(keywords_years, columns=['Year', 'Keyword'])

# Count the occurrences of each keyword per year
keyword_trends = keywords_df.groupby(['Year', 'Keyword']).size().unstack(fill_value=0)

# Plot the top 5 keywords over the years
top_keywords = keyword_trends.sum().nlargest(5).index
keyword_trends[top_keywords].plot(marker='o')
plt.title('Top 5 Keywords in Sensemaking Research Over Time')
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Frequency')
plt.legend(title='Keywords')
plt.grid(True)
plt.show()

# Print the top keywords for each year
print("### Begin of facts")
for year, group in keywords_df.groupby('Year'):
    top_keywords_year = group['Keyword'].value_counts().head(3)
    print(f"Year {year}: {', '.join(top_keywords_year.index)}")
print("### End of facts")

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_035813/dataset_selected.csv')

# Filter the dataset for the years 2010 to 2012
df_filtered = df[(df['Year'] >= 2010) & (df['Year'] <= 2012)]

# Extract keywords and titles
titles = df_filtered['Title'].str.cat(sep=' ').lower().split()
keywords = df_filtered['AuthorKeywords'].str.cat(sep=',').lower().split(',')

# Count the frequency of words in titles and keywords
title_word_count = Counter(titles)
keyword_count = Counter(keywords)

# Get the most common words in titles and keywords
top_title_words = title_word_count.most_common(5)
top_keywords = keyword_count.most_common(5)

# Print the results
print("### Begin of facts")
print("Top 5 words in titles from 2010 to 2012:")
for word, count in top_title_words:
    print(f"{word}: {count}")

print("\nTop 5 keywords from 2010 to 2012:")
for keyword, count in top_keywords:
    print(f"{keyword}: {count}")
print("### End of facts")

df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_035813/dataset_selected.csv')

keywords = df_filtered['AuthorKeywords'].str.cat(sep=',').lower().split(',')

keyword_count = Counter(keywords)

# Get the most common words in titles and keywords
top_title_words = title_word_count.most_common(5)
top_keywords = keyword_count.most_common(5)

# Print the results

print("Top 5 words in titles from 2010 to 2012:")
for word, count in top_title_words:
    print(f"{word}: {count}")

print("\nTop 5 keywords from 2010 to 2012:")
for keyword, count in top_keywords:
    print(f"{keyword}: {count}")
print("### End of facts")

import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_035813/dataset_selected.csv')

# Extract keywords and years
df['AuthorKeywords'] = df['AuthorKeywords'].str.split(', ')
keywords_by_year = df.explode('AuthorKeywords').groupby('Year')['AuthorKeywords'].apply(list)

# Count keyword occurrences by year
keyword_trends = {year: Counter(keywords) for year, keywords in keywords_by_year.items()}

# Find top keywords for each year
top_keywords_by_year = {year: keywords.most_common(3) for year, keywords in keyword_trends.items()}

# Plot the evolution of top keywords over time
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
for year, keywords in top_keywords_by_year.items():
    for keyword, count in keywords:
        plt.bar(year, count, label=keyword)

plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Keyword Frequency')
plt.title('Evolution of Top Keywords in Sensemaking Research')
plt.legend(loc='upper right')
plt.show()

# Print the top keywords by year
print("### Begin of facts")
for year, keywords in top_keywords_by_year.items():
    print(f"Year {year}: {', '.join([kw for kw, _ in keywords])}")
print("### End of facts")
